question_str:
{
    "Question": "Alex is developing a software for sports psychologists to track and predict an athlete's performance based on previous games. Alex wants to include a feature that calculates the athlete's 'hot-streaks' - a series of games where the athlete performs significantly above their average. The current code fails to identify these 'hot-streaks'. Which of the following changes should Alex make to effectively identify the 'hot-streaks'?",
    "Answer1": "Replace the '<' operator with the '>' operator in line 5",
    "Answer2": "Replace the 'average' variable with the 'performance' variable in line 3",
    "Answer3": "Replace the 'average' variable with the 'performance' variable in line 6",
    "Answer4": "Replace the 'performance' variable with the 'average' variable in line 4",
    "CorrectAnswer": "1",
    "Explanation": "A hot-streak is a period where the athlete performs better than usual. Therefore, the condition in line 5 should be 'if performance > average' instead of 'if performance < average'. This modification will allow the code to accurately identify the athlete's 'hot-streaks'.",
    "code_snippet": "number average = calculateAveragePerformance()\nrepeat with each number performance in previousGames\n    if performance < average\n        output performance\n    else\n        output 'Hot-streak'\n    end\nend"
}
